job_title: Patient Engagement Specialist in Bourne, MA
pros: Good coworkers. Very helpful and benefitd are good
cons: Communication is bad. Training not that great

job_title: Deskside Support Analyst in Hartford, CT
pros: The role allows supporting staff with desktop issues such as setups, account lockouts, and network support. Also, you will gain connections with others who work in other disciplines such as applications, security, and network support.
cons: Micro-managed and Overworked, you will be responsible to work on two different jobs at once and get sent to ground zero when you make a mistake. The staff expects you to fix problems that are not part of your support. Be expected to travel to other sites with little to no help and be held accountable for the issues at each site. I would not recommend it to anyone who wants to join IT because it is a lack of collaboration and teamwork.

job_title: Patient Service Associate in New London, CT
pros: You make great friends because of the all the awful experiences you have to go through together
cons: No additional pay for speaking an additional language , even though that means you work twice as hard. Updates are consistently taking place with no sufficient training but you will be sent to ground zero and held accountable for the smallest mistake. They allow patients to belittle you and when the patients are not , leadership is. The turn over is so high no one knows what is going on. Always short staffed, you are always working 2-3 people short staffed and fulfilling multiple roles with no extra pay.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Enfield, CT
pros: Great pay and benefits. Very diverse and inclusive.
cons: Not much flexibility with scheduling and work life balance.

job_title: School Based Therapist in New London, CT
pros: School schedule is nice for breaks
cons: Pay is not great for work

pros: The work we do is wonderful and really impacts the direct community and others across the country.
cons: There is no direct management in the Weitzman Institute and they push more degrees to advance job wise.

job_title: PSA Patient Service Associate in Hartford, CT
pros: ok benefits, not much pros
cons: toxic work environment, always understaffed

review_title: Great work community but management plays favorites
pros:
Great Work family
Flexibility
Decent salary
cons:
HR is pro management, doesn't listen to employee concerns
Lack of growth/advancement, not willing to provide opportunities to do so

pros: Worked with great people in a mission driven organization
cons: Hard being extremely underpaid at a medical non-profit because so many of the people you work with are highly compensated. The standard is a 3% raise each year, so I'm actually making less than when I started with inflation.

review_title: Offered a job and Company decided another candidate prior to start date
pros: Potential Summer off, however required to work 3 days in July.
cons: Not a month position, low pay and unreasonable expectations.

review_title: from a free clinic to a corporate office
pros: good pay. good benefits, good coworkers
cons: top heavy management with, unaffordable health insurance, benefits that require employees to complete meaningless health goals in order to get money, leadership that cares more about how they look in media and on picture than the actual care we provide. management cares more about quantity over quality across the board.

pros: Community based - out in the community
cons: Lots of running around, lots of events to attend

review_title: There are worst places to work
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in New London, CT
pros:
-Constantly busy so it makes the day go by fast
-You get a yearly raise
-Possible to get OT (with permission)
cons:
-Meetings during lunch
-Patients can be rude

pros:
Decent pay if you are able to complete your work.
Decent PTO but must find own coverage within the organization.
cons:
Too many patients per day.
Too much administrative work without enough allotted time.
Weak collaboration.

job_title: Nurse Manager in New London, CT
pros: In-house clinical research and clinical education. Progressive organization with a high minimum wage (18.50/hr), high matching contributions to retirement account, low vacancy rate. Good work/life balance, day-shift only and you get out on time. Working here means you're participating in a social movement for health care equity and justice. Great organization for registered nurses, as this organization employs a Chief Nursing Officer. The status of the nursing profession is strong in this organization, lots of nursing autonomy via a robust set of standing orders.
cons: Somewhat thinly spread management/leadership team for a large, sprawling organization. Not using Epic EMR, so a lot of home-brew data analytics of variable quality. Reliance on MS Outlook and Skype for intra-office communication, no modern groupware. Patients are self-selected as the most challenged and most challenging. Health insurance isn't great but not the worst I've had.

review_title: Wish I could give it fewer stars
pros: money- they are all getting very very rich off of poor people's healthcare
cons: backstabbing, lying, blind-eye towards flagrantly racist practitioners and executives, i don't know where to being - too depressing

review_title: Best mental health job I've had
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in New Britain, CT
pros: School based with a school calendar/schedule. Competitive base salary with plenty of opportunity for monthly bonuses if you meet productivity
cons: Upper management doesn't entertain grievances or complaints

pros: strong opportunity for promotion and make connections
cons: Hours can be a lot at times

job_title: Family Nurse Practitioner in New Britain, CT
pros:
-great colleagues-- most of the people working here are really committed to helping the underserved. 
-The company is very supportive of NPs practicing to their full scope, this is likely because CHC's VP (Margaret Flinter) is a NP herself.
- Job security
cons:
The acuity and complexity of a FQHC patient population does not fare well with the productivity expectations set forth by CHC. Very sick, often uninsured/underinsured population, requiring extensive care management and health education- none of which could be done in a 15-20 min visit, especially when providers are expected to see 20+ patients/day.
-very high provider turnover

pros: Jobs are one a dozen.
cons: No woke life balance and.lies to

job_title: Registered Medical Assistant/Office Manager in Stratford, CT
pros: Independent, SBHC is perfect for shorter hours when you have a little one at home
cons: Going to main sites. Lack of team work there.

review_title: Not a Great Fit for Advanced Professionals
pros: They pay for health benefits. It is a good learning experience for beginners who wish to work in drug treatment.
cons: This agency seeks professionals with advanced degrees, but treat and pay their staff as if they only have a GED! The money is horrible, they place clients needs above the staff's, even if a client has stolen from a staff member. They only offer a 30 minute lunch break and there is not enough time between clients to take breaks.

review_title: There are Pros & There are Cons
pros: Very mission oriented, everyone works extremely hard, and really cares
cons: There is not a lot of career trajectory

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Cromwell, CT
pros: Great values, quality patient care for all populations, hard working and dedicated employees all the way to the top
cons: Must be willing to change as swiftly as healthcare needs require

review_title: You seen a lot of patience, but the system is flexible ans supportive
job_title: Behavioral Health Specialist in New London, CT
pros: They are flexible and supportive. They help the employee
cons: Seen a lot of pt

pros: Great team environnement, independence to practice, lots of learning opportunities
cons: Could be more opportunities for growth, more bonus opportunities

pros: Time goes by fast because you're not sitting all-day
cons: It was Cold and Rainy and you have to deal with Annoying Patients

review_title: They exploit clinician, they make you see 9 to 12 patients a day, not counting groups
pros: excellent coworkers, depending the site
cons: They exploit clinician, they make you see 9 to 12 patients a day, not counting groups

pros: Mileage reimbursement! Great facilities with a miso soup machine. Love the culture that is committed to social justice and quality healthcare for all. Pods to communicate with other coworkers. Really friendly admin/management. Loan repayment plans if you're a clinician. Technology is great. Teleconferencing and internet access is excellent. Never gets boring. Some people go on to do AMAZING things. Former CMO is now Associate Director of PCPCC and Assistant Professor at UCSF. Minimum wage for everyone is 17 an hour. I really feel I am part of an organization that cares for all of its members.
cons: Strict internet filter policy means a lot of stuff related to work I can't see. It's for security reasons so it's justified, though. We are a health care organization with medical records. Security is paramount. The clinicians sometimes seem overworked, but they get paid competitively and it's part of the mission of increasing access to quality care.

job_title: Patient Services Associate in Middletown, CT
pros: The benefits and pay are pretty good.  Also there are plenty of hours for you to work.  Plenty of contact with many people on a daily basis so if you like meeting people then you will like this job.
cons: They expect you to answer phones like crazy even though they have a call center to answer calls.  Since they want you to answer calls then you can't help the patients that come to you.  Management doesn't care about you they just want to focus on the numbers so they loose touch of patient care.

pros: Hardly any pros. I appreciate the friends that I made while there. They were my support system while working for such a toxic organization.  I worked specifically for the Weitzman Institute  of CHC.
cons: The senior leadership are really toxic. They show favoritism towards certain staff and they are very condescending and rude. They treat staff like they are invisible. Don't be fooled...for an organization that is supposed to stand for fairness and integrity, they really lack that. I'm happy to be far away from this place.

job_title: Medical Provider in New Britain, CT
pros:
-clinical staff is great. Nurses, support team and other providers (MDs & NPs) all clearly care about serving a vulnerable population.
-salary is competitive
-good amount of days off (PTO and CME )
cons:
- productivity expectations are unreasonable (once fully ramped up, providers are scheduled for 4 patients per hour). 
-very complicated and sick patient population (15 min visits are never enough time)
-the health insurance they offer is terrible
- administration only cares about money
- very little employee appreciation/recognition

pros: training, insurance, hours and learning opportunities
cons: micromanagement, lack of supervision and constant turnover

pros: they have awesome team and management
cons: none none none none none
